awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Exploring the Origins of Malaria Using Ancient DNA
awd_abstract_narration:
The human species has been shaped by many biological and cultural processes, including the infectious diseases we have experienced over the millennia and our responses to those events. Given the ongoing threat of emerging infectious disease, understanding the ways in which humans and pathogens impacted one another in the past can inform infectious disease research in the present. This doctoral dissertation project examines the origins and evolution of the disease pathogen responsible for the deadliest form of human malaria (P. falciparum). This pathogen is thought to have evolved through the transfer of a gorilla parasite to humans, but the timing and anthropological context for this event and malaria’s subsequent global spread remain poorly understood. The project traces malaria’s evolutionary history through analysis of both ancient P. falciparum genomes and related great ape parasites. The project also generates new methods and tools that can be applied in other genomic research projects, fosters student training and international research collaborations, and generates new resources for public science education and outreach. 

The project is part of an international collaborative effort of geneticists and primatologists to reconstruct genomes from ancient Plasmodium falciparum and related great ape parasites. Using genomic analyses to estimate when P. falciparum first emerged as a human parasite, the co-PI and colleagues explore whether specific ecological and/or cultural factors, particularly the adoption or diversification of agriculture, may have favored this zoonotic event. Comparing ancient and modern parasite genomes, the investigators explore the timing and route of malaria’s global dissemination to understand the impact of human mobility on pathogen dispersal in the past. This project is anticipated to generate valuable, concrete resources for the broader scientific community, including genome-wide data from ancient Plasmodium falciparum and wild-living gorilla Plasmodium parasites.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Malaria represents a significant contemporary public health burden, with the WHO reporting over 260 million cases and nearly 600,000 deaths in the year 2023. Moreover, malaria has played a significant role in the evolution of our species, exerting one of the strongest selective pressures shaping the human genome. Despite its evolutionary and medical importance, major questions remain regarding the emergence, dissemination, and subsequent evolution of the most prevalent and most deadly of the human-infecting malaria species, Plasmodium falciparum. To address these open questions, this project retrieved and analyzed ancient malaria parasite DNA preserved in human skeletal remains, enabling exploration of changes in parasite genomic content through time.

Leveraging two new custom hybridization capture reagents, we retrieved the first genome-wide nuclear DNA from 36 individuals spanning 5,000 years of human history on five continents. Analysis of these datasets yielded important insights regarding the routes via which malaria spread around the globe, revealing that the parasite species P. falciparum and P. vivax likely arrived in the Americas via the trans-Atlantic slave trade and European colonial populations, respectivley. Morevoer, the new datasets provided an unprecedented view into the genetics of parasite populations from regions where malaria is now eliminated, enabling a deeper understanding of parasite genetic diversity prior to the onset of eradication efforts. Finally, analysis of parasite genetic data alongside archaeological information shed new light on the ways in which sociocultural factors such as colonization, warfare, and trade shaped malaria transmission in the past, just as they continue to do today. 

While the resources and methods piloted in this study may pave the way for future work analyzing the evolution of malaria using ancient DNA, they also have potential applications beyond the field of biological anthropology. For instance, the hybridization capture arrays developed to facilitate retrieval of miniscule amounts of poorly-preserved malaria DNA from skeletal material could enable generation of genome-wide data from dried blood spots and other archival materials commonly generated in public health contexts. Such data could yield new information relevant for malaria control efforts, such as helping to trace the emergence and spread of antrimicrobial resistance in regional parasite populations. Therefore, the capacity to explore genomic evolution in parasite populations through time may impact future work on malaria epidemiology and public health.
